Award.AwardTitle: Forming, Advancing, and Sustaining Teacher-Engineer Relationships (FASTER)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award for a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site Program at Columbia University entitled, Forming, Advancing, and Sustaining Teacher-Engineer Relationships (FASTER), under the direction of Dr. Raimondo Betti and Mr. Jay Dubner.

Columbia University's Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Sciences will use all of the resources at its disposal to develop an RET site which will provide pre-college science teachers with a mentored engineering laboratory experience. The proposed RET site will place ten public middle and high school teachers in Columbia's research laboratories headed by faculty members with appointments in the School of Engineering and Applied Science for 8 weeks in each of two consecutive summers. An additional secondary school teacher will work in an environmental engineering laboratory at James Cook University in Australia for 6 weeks. Nine of the ten domestic placed teachers will be from the New York metropolitan area. The tenth teacher will be from a secondary school in Singapore. Their research experience will be enhanced through weekly pedagogical meetings.

FASTER's primary goal is to facilitate long-term collaborative partnerships between secondary school science teachers and university researchers by involving teachers in engineering research and helping them translate their new knowledge into classroom activities. The ultimate recipients will be New York City area students whose population are largely underrepresented in the sciences and engineering. Columbia University faculty will provide teachers with opportunities to gain hands on experience with the tools and materials of science and engineering in an environment attuned to professional development. Thus, teachers understanding of engineering and their ability to develop and lead inquiry- and standards-based science classes and laboratories will improve. In addition, the teachers will be exposed to a new perspective and a different professional culture which enables them to communicate the vitality and dynamism of applied science to their students and colleagues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Academy of Engineering’s 2010 report ‘Standards for K-12 Engineering Education?’ states that there is limited experience with K-12 engineering education in the U.S. and a lack of qualified teachers. The National Science Board’s 2010 report sounded the alarm that the United States is failing to sufficiently identify and nurture the next generation of high-achieving innovators in the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) field and that puts our nation at risk for long-term prosperity. To address this serious problem, Columbia University’s Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, with support from the National Science Foundation’s Directorate for Engineering, used its resources to develop an RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) site which provided pre-college science teachers with a mentored engineering research experience, coupled with pedagogical support.

Columbia University’s RET site, Forming, Advancing, and Sustaining Teacher-Engineer Relationships (FASTER), placed middle and high public school teachers in Columbia’s research laboratories headed by faculty members with appointments to the School of Engineering and Applied Science for 8 weeks in each of two consecutive summers. Each year one science teacher worked in an environmental engineering laboratory at James Cook University in Australia.

FASTER successfully met its primary goal of facilitating long-term collaborative partnerships between pre-college science teachers and university researchers. The ultimate recipients are New York City public school students whose population are largely underrepresented in the sciences and engineering. Columbia University faculty reasoned that providing teachers with opportunities to gain hands-on experience with the tools and materials of science and engineering in an environment attuned to professional development would have many beneficial effects. Teachers’ understanding of engineering helped them to develop and lead inquiry- and standards-based science classes and laboratories. The teachers were exposed to a new perspective and a different professional culture which enabled them to communicate the vitality and dynamism of applied science to their students and colleagues.

The partnerships between engineering faculty, graduate students, and science teachers moved the scientist away from the traditional roles they’ve played in public education (e.g.; science fair judges) into more interactive and authentic roles of sharing with learners the enterprises in which they work. Doctoral students visited the teacher’s classroom. Few high school students have ever met an engineer, and fewer still were acquainted with young engineers in training. These graduate students became role models as ‘near peers.’ Engineers gave lectures to the program participants during the weekly summer pedagogical sessions. The lectures were recorded so they may be used by the teachers and their colleagues as part of their classroom instruction. FASTER participants continue to collaborate with their research groups. This allows the teacher to stay informed about the status and findings of the engineering research in which they were trained.

Over the course of the NSF award, 25 Engineering Research Fellowships were awarded to pre-college science teachers. Twelve Columbia University and four James Cook University (Australia) engineering faculty opened their research groups in support of the FASTER program.
